header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: One Precept Part 7

central_thesis: The text posits that the essential spiritual path involves beginning service to the Creator 'not for its own sake' (Lo Lishma), a necessary preliminary stage that ultimately leads to true selfless service 'for its own sake' (Lishma). It further elaborates on the nature and infallibility of prophetic truth, asserting that true prophecy is validated by tangible, beneficial outcomes for the generation, irrespective of the prophet's individual 'degree of preparation'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Giving satisfaction to his Maker unknowingly
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the core concept that serving the Creator must initially begin 'not for its own sake' (Lo Lishma). It asserts that expecting humanity to immediately serve 'for its own sake' is unrealistic and that the journey from self-interested service to selfless devotion is a challenging path, often leading to spiritual 'casualties'. The transformation from Lo Lishma to Lishma is presented as an internal process dependent on personal preparation and control over one's heart.

structure_content.chapter_title: According to prophetic truth in a corporeal parameter
structure_content.summary: Prophecy is discussed in terms of its practical manifestation and acceptance. True prophetic abundance is received through 'permutations of the letters' in a way that provides clear, obvious benefits for the personal issues of the generation. This 'physical success' validates the prophecy, allowing the Creator's Word to be accepted even when people initially engage with it 'not for its own sake', as this is the manner in which the Creator prepared them.

structure_content.chapter_title: Mistakes or lies can never happen in prophecy
structure_content.summary: This section firmly establishes the infallibility of true prophecy. It argues that error cannot originate from the 'Light of the Truth' of the Creator. Prophecy is likened to rain and snow, which descend to fulfill their purpose and do not return unaccomplished, implying a divine guarantee of its manifestation and truthfulness.

structure_content.chapter_title: A long and short road in prophecy
structure_content.summary: While prophecy itself is infallible, the means of its reception vary among prophets. Differences in 'degree of preparation' affect how directly and clearly a prophet receives the divine message. Prophets with a 'lesser degree' may attract a greater number of 'letter combinations' (channels or vessels) for the prophecy to reach their comprehension, making the path seem 'longer', yet the essence of the prophetic light remains pure and without mistake.

key_concepts.term: Lo Lishma (Not for its own sake)
key_concepts.definition: The initial stage of spiritual service or study, where actions are motivated by self-interest, external rewards, or a desire for personal benefit rather than pure, selfless devotion to the Creator. The text emphasizes this as a necessary and unavoidable starting point for all individuals.

The ultimate stage of spiritual service, characterized by pure, selfless devotion and a sole desire to give satisfaction to the Creator, without any expectation of personal gain or reward. This state is achieved through a transformative process that begins with Lo Lishma.

Divine communication that is inherently infallible and guaranteed to manifest its intended purpose. Its authenticity is demonstrated by its ability to bring about tangible, physical success and benefit for the generation to whom it is revealed, thus securing its acceptance.

The spiritual and internal readiness of an individual to receive prophecy. This 'greatness or smallness' determines the directness and clarity of the prophetic message received. A lesser degree of preparation may necessitate more 'channels and vessels' (letter combinations) for the prophecy to be comprehended, creating a 'longer road' to its understanding.

practical_system.description: The practical system advocated is primarily one of dedicated spiritual engagement and internal transformation. The core 'mechanic' is the conscious and consistent practice of service to the Creator, even if the initial motivation is self-serving ('Lo Lishma'). The author implies that persistent effort in this preliminary stage, coupled with self-control and proper preparation (which is not explicitly detailed but implied as vital), will naturally lead to the higher state of selfless service ('Lishma'). The text also suggests that discerning true prophecy involves observing its practical benefits and the 'physical success' it brings to the community, making the outcome a key indicator of its divine origin.

relevant_quotes.text: One should never hope that there would come a time in which the world would be so evolved that everyone could start serving the Creator “for its own sake”.
Rather - as it has always been and still is today and will forever be - everyone who is serving the Creator must begin becoming engaged with this service 'not for its own sake'.
And from this he will achieve “for its own sake”.
And what great nation is there, that has statutes and ordinances as righteous as all this law which I set before you this day?" (Deuteronomy 4:8)

Because how can mistake creep into the Light of the Truth that originates from the Creator? Rather, it surely is like the rain and the snow that come down from heaven to earth and does not return until it accomplished what it was sent for.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is profoundly relevant to students of Kabbalah and esoteric traditions that emphasize ethical monotheism and the rectification of desire. It specifically addresses a foundational concept within the Lurianic and Ashlagian Kabbalah concerning the nature of spiritual intention and service (Avodah). By clarifying the necessity of beginning with 'Lo Lishma' as a gateway to 'Lishma', it provides a practical framework for navigating the inherent complexities of spiritual development, particularly in an egocentric world. The discussion on prophecy offers a unique perspective on the validation and reception of divine communication, linking spiritual truth to tangible outcomes, which resonates with pragmatic approaches in certain magical traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those engaged with the writings of Rav Ashlag. It is also highly relevant for esoteric practitioners and occultists interested in Jewish mysticism, the philosophy of divine service, the nature of revelation, and the internal work required for spiritual transformation. Individuals studying comparative religion, mysticism, or the psychological dimensions of spiritual practice would also find value in its deep philosophical insights.
